I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  On 26 December 2004, a massive earthquake in the Indian Ocean triggered a huge tidal 
wave, a tsunami. It struck more than 1,000 kilometers, or two thirds, of Sri Lanka’s coastline, 
starting from Jaffna in the north, all of the eastern and southern coast, and part of the west 
coast, as far as Chilaw, north of Colombo. As of 25 January 2005, official figures indicated that 
30,957 people were dead, 196 injured, and 35,644 missing, but the count is likely to increase. 
With people returning to their homes or staying with their relatives, the number of displaced 
people has fallen to 502,456; 1 million to 2 million out of a population of 19 million are affected 
by the disaster. About 200,000 have lost their livelihoods. The displaced are sheltered in some 
625 refugee camps, often temples and schools. Around 120,000 houses were damaged, of 
which more than 78,000 were completely destroyed. Coastal infrastructure (roads, railway, 
power, telecommunications, water supply, fishing ports) was significantly affected, but a precise 
assessment of the damage is ongoing. Given its concentration on the northern and eastern 
coastal areas, the tsunami has affected a disproportionately high share of the poor who are 
engaged in fishing, subsistence agriculture, and small-scale trading activities. The burden of the 
destruction wrought by the tsunami is not distributed evenly; vulnerable groups (the elderly and 
young, and women) are particularly prone to exploitation and abuse, especially in camps for 
internally displaced persons. The human impact, in terms of lives lost and livelihoods and 
families destroyed, has been staggering.  
 
2.  In February 2005, the Government requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide technical assistance (TA) for preparing emergency assistance, including refining the 
damage  assessment  and  implementation  strategies.  ADB,  through  the  Sri  Lanka  Resident 
Mission,  reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  goals,  implementation 
arrangements,  cost  estimates,  and  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  (as  outlined  in  the 
technical assistance framework in Appendix 1).1 
 
3.  The tsunami has resulted in massive destruction of physical and social infrastructure 
throughout the coastal areas (Appendix 2, Map). The Government, the Liberation Tigers of 
Tamil Eelam (LTTE), and the donor community are coordinating in a post-tsunami recovery and 
reconstruction program to (i) meet the immediate requirements of people who have lost their 
homes and livelihoods and help them resume their normal lives as quickly as possible; and (ii) 
to address the short- and medium-term rehabilitation needs of the tsunami-affected areas. 
ADB’s assistance will incorporate lessons learned from the post-conflict needs assessment2 
conducted in 2003, mainly the continuing need for a balanced and transparent development in a 
conflict-sensitive manner—the “do no harm approach”—given the urgent reconstruction needs. 
  
II.  ISSUES 
4.  In a meeting of development partners on 29 December 2004, and with the Ministry of 
Finance on 30 December 2004, it was decided that ADB, the Japan Bank for International 
Cooperation (JBIC), the World Bank, and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) 
will support the Government in developing a joint needs assessment (JNA) to (i) assess the 
damage inflicted by the tsunami, and to (ii) devise strategies on how to implement post-tsunami 
reconstruction programs. In the light of the Group of Seven (G7) meeting on 12 January 2005 
that gave the multilateral institutions the mandate to report on the state of the economy and

costs of reconstruction before the next G7 meeting on 4 February 2005, a two-phased approach 
toward the JNA was adopted.3 The first phase (9–31 January 2005) consisted of a report geared 
to G7 requirements, presenting restoration costs, and assessing the macroeconomic impact of 
the tsunami. Total damage was estimated at 4.4% of gross domestic product (GDP), while 
restoration costs in the short and medium term were projected at $1.5 billion.4  
 
5.  The  second  phase  starting  early  February  will  last  for  6–8  weeks.  It  will  focus  on 
consultations with all stakeholders, refinement of recovery and reconstruction strategies, and 
formulation of implementation strategies. While it is relatively straightforward to assess the 
damage and to define what needs to be done, more work is needed to devise assistance to 
ensure speedy, efficient, and transparent implementation. The finalized JNA can then become 
the basis for donor coordination, including ADB, in funding further reconstruction operations, 
and  will  directly  feed  into  preparing  the  emergency  assistance  loan.  Interventions  will  be 
prioritized and supported either through joint cofinancing or parallel projects, depending on the 
modalities available to interested donors.  For this TA, the following will be considered:  
  
(i)  Rehabilitation  under  ADB  assistance  will  include  elements  of  post-conflict 
rehabilitation identified by the needs assessment conducted in 2003.  
(ii)  The second phase of the JNA should be undertaken jointly, reflecting the need to 
work closely with the numerous Government ministries and agencies involved in 
rehabilitation, and with the representative organizations of the north and east. 
(iii)  The  area  to  be  covered  should  include  all  districts  affected  by  the  tsunami 
(Appendix 2) that are either under Government or LTTE control.  
 
6.  The TA and the rehabilitation activities that may result from it will allow ADB to continue 
to play its important role in rehabilitation and donor coordination, and to develop other timely 
interventions.  
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
7.  The TA’s goal, purpose, and output are set out in the TA framework in Appendix 1. The 
goal is to restore and improve basic living conditions for people affected by the tsunami in 
coastal areas and for people affected by the conflict. The purpose is to prepare implementation 
strategies for emergency assistance programs and to help finalize the JNA of rehabilitation 
needs in the affected districts. Implementation strategies that can be used for the emergency 
assistance loan will be prepared in accordance with ADB’s Disaster and Emergency Assistance 
Policy5 and related operational procedures and policies, and incorporate the Guiding Principles. 
The Guiding Principles were prepared by the development partners in consultation with key 
stakeholders and the Government (Appendix 4). These principles stress the importance of 
conflict  sensitivity,  subsidiarity,  transparency  and  consultation,  as  well  as  coordination. 
Subsidiarity, or the delegation of program implementation and planning to the lowest possible 
level of government, is considered key to equitable and transparent implementation. These 
principles  are  envisaged  to  guide  all  development  cooperation  related  to  post-tsunami 
reconstruction. The output will be (i) implementation strategies for emergency assistance; (ii)

planning and coordination capacity at the district and provincial levels to ensure subsidiarity 
works,  as  well  as  strengthened  community  consultation,  coordination  of  aid  inflows,  and 
implementation of projects.  
 
8.  This TA will support Sri Lanka’s efforts to mobilize funding for a large-scale medium-term 
rehabilitation  program  in  the  tsunami-affected  areas,  and  help  crystallize  the  different 
administrative and institutional arrangements for the successful implementation of livelihood 
restoration in the north, east, and south.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  In planning the assistance, it is important to be sensitive to its geographical spread 
among the various affected areas and population groups, and to substantially involve key 
stakeholders such as high-level LTTE cadres in the North East. Given the importance of fast 
and efficient implementation of any post-tsunami reconstruction assistance, ADB’s emergency 
assistance  will,  to  the  extent  possible,  make  use  of  existing  and  successful  project 
implementation and delivery mechanisms through projects such as the North East Community 
Restoration and Development Project,7 Conflict-Affected Areas Rehabilitation Project,8 and the 
North East Coastal Community Development Project.9 Outside the North East, the Southern 
Province Rural Economic Advancement Project,10 the Road Network Improvement Project,11 the 
Coastal  Resources  Management  Project,12  and  the  Rural  Finance  Development  Program13 
could be used as a platform to quickly deliver aid to affected areas.  
 
10.  The TA will review existing assessments by the Government and LTTE. Extensive field 
visits, including consultations with people affected by the conflict, will be conducted to verify 
previous assessments and add new information. It will develop implementation arrangements 
for a post-tsunami recovery strategy and identify gaps in the planning and/or implementation 
ability  of  relevant  agencies  and  field  technical  assistants.  At  least  two  major  consultative 
workshops will be held to discuss implementation strategies, in addition to smaller seminars and 
meetings at the district level.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The TA will be administered by ADB. The TA will be carried out in accordance with 
ADB’s safeguards policy requirements specified in the Disaster and Emergency Assistance 
Policy. The Executing Agency will be the Task Force for Rebuilding the Nation (TAFREN), 
which is tasked by the Government to develop the reconstruction program.15 The TA will fund 
other representative organizations in the North East. Responsibility and guidance to prepare the 
emergency  loan  lie  broadly  with  ADB  and  the  Government,  in  close  collaboration  with  all 
stakeholders. Inputs to the JNA will be mandated by the JNA steering group. To avoid overlaps 
in the field, field visits and surveys necessary to prepare the emergency assistance loan will be 
a joint exercise where possible.   
 
13.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months. It will include an element of retroactive 
financing of about $60,000, mainly related to the preparation of the first phase of the JNA, as it 
has commenced in January 2005. It is expected to be completed by 31 December 2005. The 
input of domestic consultants will be about 35 person-months and international consultants, 27 
person–months  (Appendix  3).  Consultants  will  be  selected  on  a  direct  selection  basis  in 
accordance with ADB’s Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy,16 and ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants by ADB and Its Borrowers.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Sri Lanka to be financed on a grant basis from the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund for 
the Sri Lanka Post-Tsunami Needs Assessment and Preparation for Emergency Assistance 
Implementation Strategies, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

closely with line ministries and the Ministry of Finance.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Work 
 
1.  The goal, purpose, and outputs of the technical assistance (TA) are set out in the 
accompanying technical assistance framework. The TA will be implemented in accordance with 
the Disaster Policy and Emergency Assistance Policy1 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
Within this framework, the consulting services will do the following:  
 
(i)   Provide inputs to the initial implementation of the emergency assistance loan to 
address  rehabilitation  and  development  in  sectors  such as  transport,  power, 
water supply and sanitation, coastal resources and community development, and 
microfinance/rural  finance  sectors  and  other  crosscutting  issues  related  to 
livelihood restoration.  
(ii)   Provide inputs to both phases of the Joint Needs Assessment (JNA). The inputs 
will be mandated by the JNA steering committee, filling gaps in funding and 
expertise for the Government and development partners.  
(iii)   Strengthen the capacity of key agencies at the district and provincial levels.  
 
2.  To successfully complete the multitask assignment and achieve maximum flexibility, 
consultants will be engaged as individuals. The outline terms of reference of the activities to be 
completed under the TA by the international and domestic consultants include, but are not 
necessarily limited to, the tasks listed below.  
 
3.  The individual specialists have the following allocated time for the overall TA, which will 
be allocated among the three focus areas.  
 
•  Team leader/infrastructure and management specialist    (6 person-months) 
•  Livelihood/village community specialist       (5 person -months) 
•  Project preparation and implementation specialists     (3 person-months) 
•  Procurement specialist            (1 person-month) 
•  Resettlement expert            (1 person-month) 
•  Information technology/database management consultant  (5 person-months, 
  (domestic) 
•  Planning/programming specialist        (3 person-months) 
•  Specialist consultants (international)       (4 person-months) 
•  Specialist consultants (domestic)        (4 person-months) 
•  Technical assistants, research, liaison (domestic)    (30 person-months) 
 
4.  International and domestic specialists will be required, including but not limited to, (i) 
town/community planners; (ii) hydrologist; (iii) coastal defense/harbor engineer; (iv) institutional 
specialist; (v) training specialist; and (vi) building standards engineer. 
 
5.  Some of these specialists may be supplied by other development partners. Crosscutting 
issues (conflict sensitivity, gender etc.) will be addressed by specialists from the Sri Lanka 
Resident Mission, and working groups working directly under the phase-2 needs assessment 
steering committee. The TA will also draw on, and work closely with, sector expertise from 
operational divisions within ADB’s South Asia Department.

1.  Specific Activities  
 
6.  The activities to be undertaken by the assessment team will include the following: 
 
(i)  Inputs for the preparation of the emergency assistance 
 
(a)  Focus  on  existing  assessment  reports,  feasibility  studies,  and  other

development approaches used in project initiatives including approaches

(b)  Develop an implementation strategy, including institutional strengthening

(c)  Develop  implementation  mechanisms  to  ensure  fair  targeting  of

(d)  Document the impact and lessons learned in implementing the ongoing

(e)  Prepare the baseline data for emergency assistance. 
(f)  Develop a model for monitoring governance issues and also develop a

(g)  Conduct a conflict sensitivity assessment of the affected areas. 
(h)  Initiate  and  sustain  the  consultative  process  in  key  areas  of  ADB’s

(i)  Prepare sector assessment reports with summary descriptions for each

  (ii)  Needs assessment

Government through field visits. 
(b)  Phase 2. This component will contribute to the JNA under the mandate of 
the multi-agency JNA steering group. The draft terms of reference are in

2.  Schedule 
 
7.  It is anticipated that the consultants will mobilize around mid-January 2005 and complete 
the assignment in mid-August 2005. Capacity building at the district and provincial levels will be 
done around April 2005 and will remain, as needed, up to December 2005.  
 
B.  Proposed Phase 2: Terms of Reference for the Joint Needs Assessment (Draft) 
 
8.  The objective of the JNA’s second phase is to further develop and build consensus 
around a national reconstruction plan or similar document that embodies the concerns of all 
segments of society and provides the basis for a concerted and successful reconstruction effort, 
conducive to long-term development and peaceful coexistence. The terms of reference for the 
proposed phase 2 of the needs assessment include, but are not limited to, the following: 
 
(i)  Obtain  and  assess  national  policies  pertaining  to  land  tenure/resettlement, 
coastal development setback, fisheries development, procurement, cash-for-work 
payments,  business  recovery  mechanisms,  international  non-governmental 
organizations registration, and definition of tsunami-affected areas vs. conflict-
affected areas. 
(ii)  Refine (as needed) the needs assessment at the sector level in consultation with 
a broader range of stakeholders than was possible during the first phase (for 
example,  through  additional  discussion  with  line  ministries,  civil-society 
organizations active in the sector, district representatives, affected populations). 
(iii)  Together with other stakeholders, develop concrete proposals and give advice on 
how rehabilitation and reconstruction activities will be implemented, keeping in 
mind (a) the Guiding Principles (Appendix 4) developed jointly by development 
partners and accepted by the Government, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam 
and  Non-governmental  organizations  (represented  by  the  Consortium  of 
Humanitarian  Assistance,  etc.),  if  they  are  endorsed;  and  (b)  the  contextual 
concerns highlighted during the first phase of the JNA. 
(iv)  Facilitate  the  development  of  standards  and  other  technical  aspects  of 
reconstruction activities that are consistent with international best practices by 
supplying information to the authorities and parties so they can make informed 
decisions on the most suitable solutions for Sri Lanka. 
(v)  Promote and carry out, in coordination and cooperation with the relevant parties’ 
analyses, assessment and planning at the local level to facilitate reconstruction 
activities in a manner sensitive to the local situation. 
(vi)  Help  develop  a  consultation  process  that  will  ensure  that  the  proposed 
reconstruction activities are firmly grounded in local realities. In doing so, interact 
with the central and local governments, civil society, and other stakeholders to 
ensure  that  the  consultation  process  is  meaningful  but  feasible,  taking  into 
account  that  (a)  time  is  short  before  reconstruction  activities  will  start,  (b) 
disaster-affected people may be tired of meeting relief/reconstruction operators 
without seeing tangible benefits resulting from such visits and consultations, and 
(c) access to some affected areas is logistically difficult.

12  Appendix 4 
(vii)  Facilitate the linkage of relief and reconstruction plans and activities (particularly 
in critical areas such as housing and livelihood) to ensure that the transition takes 
place with minimum disruption and personal cost to the disaster-affected people. 
(viii)  Promote  coordination  of  external  and  domestic  assistance  (including  that 
supplied by Government sources and NGOs) within the framework of the national 
reconstruction plan to maximize use of resources and create synergy in the 
assistance provided by different sources. 
 
9.  Deliverables. Frequent re-editing of the first phase of the JNA report is not likely to yield 
significant benefits. While adjustments should be made as necessary as a result of additional 
findings,  the  focus  of  phase  2  will  be  on  (i)  identifying  and  documenting  approaches  for 
implementing reconstruction and (ii) deepening the analysis at the local level. Deliverables will 
include the following: 
 
(i)  by mid-April at the latest, a report focusing on the modalities and approach to 
delivering short and medium-term reconstruction and livelihood restoration; 
(ii)  by mid-April at the latest, a proposed plan to coordinate external assistance with 
domestic resources to achieve the objectives of the national reconstruction plan, 
with concrete indications of sector of activity for key development partners and, if 
possible, indicative amounts; 
(iii)  as  needed,  brief  notes  or  reports  on  specific  technical  issues  geared  to 
presenting the salient facts and options to the relevant decision makers; and 
(iv)  inputs into reconstruction planning activities at the local level.

Appendix 5  13 
GUIDING PRINCIPLES OF THE RECOVERY AND RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY 
 
1.  As the key stakeholders, including the Government, the disaster-affected communities, 
donor organizations (public and private), civil-society organizations, the Liberation Tigers of 
Tamil Eelam and others begin to rebuild the shattered coastline, some critical aspects for the 
recovery strategy must be recognized. The reconstruction strategy should thus be built on a set 
of guiding principles, drawing from international experience in disasters, and bearing in mind the 
special political circumstances of Sri Lanka. Such guiding principles, to be owned and adopted 
by the Government and all key stakeholders, include the following: 
 
2.  The recovery strategy should be conflict-sensitive, and at the very least do no harm to 
the  peace  process  while  always  attempting  to  strengthen  it.  To  do  so,  the  allocation  of 
resources, domestic and international, should be strictly guided by the identified needs and local 
priorities,  without  discrimination  on  the  basis  of  political,  religious,  ethnic,  or  gender 
considerations.  Reconstruction  interventions  should  be  done  in  such  a  way  as  to  build 
confidence between different actors in the process. Reconstruction should similarly be sensitive 
to the impact on neighboring but unaffected communities.  
 
3.  The  strategy  should  be  based  on  the  principle  of  subsidiarity,  meaning  each 
reconstruction activity should be designed and implemented at the lowest competent tier of 
Government. While the central Government should play lead in setting standards, policies, and 
principles,  subsidiarity  allows  for  locally  appropriate  solutions  and  enables  a  range  of 
subnational structures and organizations to channel funds. The recovery plan (which should be 
disaggregated to the district level) would provide for capacity building and strengthening at 
various levels of governance, but especially district and Provincial Secretaries as well as local 
civil-society organizations.   
 
4.  The recovery strategy should focus on the medium- and long-term needs of the victims. 
Therefore, consultation with local disaster-affected communities and stakeholders is essential, 
and local communities should be empowered to make their own decisions during recovery, and 
participate fully in reconstruction activities. All interventions need to respond to clearly identified 
and articulated needs of local communities, respecting local religion, culture, structures, and 
customs.  This  is  especially  important  with  respect  to  the  policies  related  to  shelter  and 
relocation, which should not proceed without such full consultation. Communities should be 
assisted to return to their original homes as swiftly as possible. To maximize the speed of 
recovery, local capacities should be harnessed as far as possible.   
 
5.  Communication and transparency are needed in decision making and implementation. 
Mechanisms should ensure access to information on policies, entitlements, and implementation 
procedures, and permit feedback to implementing authorities, as well as grievance redress. 
Similarly, mechanisms to ensure transparency in resource use and comprehensive accounting 
need to be created, at the aggregate, program, and beneficiary levels, accompanied by effective 
monitoring and evaluation systems, to permit a full accounting to Parliament, development 
partners, civil society, and the disaster-affected communities of resources deployed from all 
sources. All parties will adopt a policy of zero tolerance for corruption in this joint effort. 
 
6.  Reconstruction  processes  should  reduce  future  vulnerabilities  to  natural  hazards, 
including floods, cyclones, and landslides. A multi-hazard risk approach should be used during 
the recovery phase to ensure that communities and assets are less vulnerable to impacts of 
future disasters, while balancing the social costs of excessive resettlement.  The approach

14  Appendix 5 
should  be  guided  by  international  standards  and  best  practices  in  design  and  asset 
management. 
 
7.  All the above considerations suggest a number of factors that need to be built into the 
analysis of individual interventions. They should be analyzed for their potential impact on the 
conflict,  and,  for  long-term  sustainability,  such  interventions  should  also  incorporate 
considerations such as governance, gender-sensitivity, environment, resettlement/land issues, 
and human rights concerns. The process should be guided by international standards and best 
practice for protection, with special attention to the needs of vulnerable groups. 
 
8.  If debt relief is granted to Sri Lanka as part of the financing package, it would be 
especially important to deploy the resources so released in a transparent way for the benefit of 
the victims, and for such resource use to be carefully monitored.    
 
9.  A coordinated approach is critical to ensure that the above principles are followed and to 
prevent  duplication  or  overlap  in  activities.  Development  partners  should  adopt  codes  of 
behavior that will minimize the burden on overextended Government administration, not least by 
maximizing their own coordination. Coordination should not just be between the Government 
and donors but involve all stakeholders, including civil society, the business community, and 
international NGOs, which have resources that will not pass through the Government. Local 
capacity will need to be created for such coordination.   
 
 
 
Colombo, January 27, 2005
